questions.text: People I regularly pray WITH (not just for) are ...

answers.4: regular — I have consistent prayer partners
answers.5: integral — shared prayer is a core part of my life
answers.3: some — I pray with people sometimes

questions.text: Relationships where we discuss Scripture and what God is teaching us are ...

answers.4: regular — I have ongoing spiritual conversations
answers.5: rich — mutual learning is woven through my relationships
answers.1: nonexistent — I don't have these conversations

questions.text: People who know my real spiritual state (not just the public version) are ...

answers.4: several — they know most of it
answers.5: my inner circle — they know the truth
answers.2: maybe one — and even they don't know everything

questions.text: When others challenge my spiritual life, I ...

answers.3: sometimes receive it, sometimes get defensive
answers.1: don't let them — no one has that access

questions.text: Investment in others' spiritual lives compared to what I receive is ...

answers.5: deeply mutual — we sharpen each other consistently
answers.1: one-sided — I mostly receive or mostly give

remediation.advice: Spiritual fellowship requires vulnerability — letting others see your real spiritual state. If you're isolated spiritually, it's usually pride (not wanting to appear weak) or fear (not trusting others with your struggles). Start with one person. Be honest. See what happens.

scripture.text: Therefore, confess your sins to one another and pray for one another, that you may be healed.
